name: (3beta,4alpha,8alpha,17xi,20xi)-4,14-dimethyl-8,9-epoxycholestan-3-ol
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-1934
Reason: 1,1,2,3,4-pentachloro-2,5-benzodioxine has a melting point that we can compare to the compound sesamolin. The basic unit for our comparison will be benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C (according to the CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics, 49th Edition, 1968-1969). The structural modifications we need to consider are the presence of two additional phenyl rings. Phenyl groups, when connected to a benzene ring, tend to increase the melting point due to the enhancement of the crystalline structure and the increase in molecular weight. In the case of 1,1,2,3,4-pentachloro-2,5-benzodioxine, we have two additional phenyl rings linked in a linear fashion, which would notably augment the melting point. Each additional phenyl group can be estimated to add approximately 100°C to the melting point due to increased pi-pi interactions, rigidity, and molecular weight.
